body: @xrmx Yes it has, closing ticket now.
Can you paste a few rows of your db and the query generated by caravel? Looks like time/date column in your db is not getting interpreted as timestamps

Checkbox tries to fetch UserDBModelView class from caravel/views.py. One solution is to create a class named UserDBModelView in views.py and inherit original UserDBModelView class from flask_appbuilder.security.views

from flask_appbuilder.security.views import UserDBModelView

class UserDBModelView(UserDBModelView):
    pass

@georgeke Interesting idea about the background queries. It could impact slower query systems though (Hive launching multiple queries would eat up cluster resources). Having global timeouts might also be tricky as some users will want to run some slower queries.

Maybe we could have a query timeout per slice, similar to cache timeout? This would be the number of seconds the query has to run before it will be terminated. I think the `connect_args` allows for timeout, so it would be sent with the query. Maybe this timeout could also be provided in the slice editor? Again, probably not the best solution, just brainstorming.
_caravel --help_ may give you some hints on how to fix that.
@rhp4515 i think you have missed the bug report content :)
if you mean  `caravel runserver --timeout` then i've already set that to 3000
@rohanmonga if it's not gunicorn, do you have any backtrace in caravel logs?
Please post the backtrace from caravel logs. And close the other duplicated issue you have opened.
I was searching a bit for the link color but no 🎲 yet, I think it must be one of the `@...-link-color-...` variables.

There's a timeout flag in the runserver command. Try:
`caravel runserver -t 600`

@mistercrunch I am running it with `-t 3000`. the query is still running and when it finishes it gets cached as well. the frontend seems to be timing out

@xrmx there is nothing in caravel logs

I see the same issue when I run fabmanager create-admin -app caravel

There was mistake when I copied the ../caravel.db sql-lite database. I copied it and added the path to the caravel_config.py and the machine migration worked perfectly.

@lucky2you If you reviewed the adapter-code in the caravel-kylin branch, you can see the solutions right now is not that good. I'd like to move all the adapter-code to ORM level( in Pykylin ), but really lack of time to finish this.
This appears to be coming from flask-migrate or alembic itself, some sort of off-by-one error when stamping the migration into the database.
Very glad to have you on board!

Re-opening the issue as I understood the issue correctly.
- when the data stored in druid in null, Caravel shows as 0. 
- users may add the value shown in the filter, which will result in druid query like this 
  `
  "filter": {
  "type": "selector",
  "dimension": "id_type",
  "value": 0
  }
  `
- If the user uses null in the filter,  the resulting druid query is 'null' 
  `
  "filter": {
  "type": "selector",
  "dimension": "id_type",
  "value": 'null'
  }
  `
- Both of these are incorrect, the following filter will work.
  `
  "filter": {
  "type": "selector",
  "dimension": "id_type",
  "value": null
  }
  `

I'll send PR for this. 
cc @x4base and @mistercrunch please suggest.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/7180053/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/7180053)

Coverage increased (+0.01%) to 81.023% when pulling **ee00db2086dbf9144ecc0321c36c166da44e4c91 on plumbeo:bind-address** into **f43e5f18d58c73b10aea3d7ca603e916bed5ed9e on airbnb:master**.

The exception is due to Presto misinterpreting the date as a varchar.  In your field definition of the table, add `timestamp '{}'` to database expression.  It will change the SQL query from `fieldname <= '2016-07-20 07:00:00'` to `fieldname <= timestamp '2016-07-20 07:00:00'`.  

See https://prestodb.io/docs/current/functions/datetime.html. Requires a change in pyhive for sqlalchemy which currently doesn't handle time conversions correctly.
What about using _-b_ as gunicorn does?

@xrmx I used _-a_ because caravel already uses the _-p_ flag to select the port while gunicorn uses _-b_ to select both address and port at the same time, so I thought using the same flag with a different meaning would be confusing. I can change it, in case.
@plumbeo yeah, makes sense :)
@georgeke, the type is timestamp. @volkmar, Worked like a charm. Thanks a lot

@joshwalters Apologies for the slow response. I like the idea of having a timeout per slice for further customization if needed, but I'm not sure what the implementation of this would look like? The timeout on the gunicorn workers are set when the server starts so I'm unsure how the incoming requests can affect the timeout.

I'm curious how you guys are doing it right now with long hive queries, do you just have a large timeout on the gunicorn workers?

Comments addressed, mergin'

My connection string is teradata://user:password@dbhost/ . The dialect I'm using is a modified version of Teradata's SqlAlchemy with more methods implemented (https://github.com/mrbungie/sqlalchemy-teradata/tree/feature/dialect_get_columns) and with some fixes regarding schemas.

I explored the dialect looking for something and found nothing. But like I said, it's weird because it only happens with MySQL as Caravel's backend.

More info:
Original dialect: https://github.com/Teradata/sqlalchemy-teradata
https://developer.teradata.com/tools/articles/teradata-sqlalchemy-introduction
